description:
Fixing methane leaks is good business!


Methane is a potent greenhouse gas. When released into the atmosphere, methane is a problem. Most of these releases are unintentional leaks. And if these leaks are not addressed, they can have a significant impact on global warming.

Estimates today suggest that "methane is responsible for almost a third of the 1.2 degrees Celsius (2.2 degrees Fahrenheit) that global temperatures have risen since the industrial era."

Fortunately, effective technologies exist to detect and repair these methane leaks. The costs of fixing these leaks can also be offset by the associated savings in energy and emissions, making a win-win situation for both industry and the environment.

In other words, fixing methane leaks isn't just important in the battle against climate change -- done right, it can pay for itself.

The real question is: How do we get oil and gas businesses (from the wellhead to the meter) to make the necessary system improvements to fix our systemic methane leaks? This is not a cheap and easy task! Let’s hope that the PG&E precedent (regulated utility that pled guilty to felony arson and 84 counts of manslaughter, then started massive overhauling of network) is not a signal of what’s to come.

Read for yourself at The Conversation US:

https://lnkd.in/gfc3AZQy


#technology #energy #oilandgas
dateposted: Fixing methane leaks is good business!

Methane is a potent greenhouse gas. When released into the atmosphere, methane is a problem. Most of these releases are unintentional leaks. And if these leaks are not addressed, they can have a significant impact on global warming.
Estimates today suggest that "methane is responsible for almost a third of the 1.2 degrees Celsius (2.2 degrees Fahrenheit) that global temperatures have risen since the industrial era."

Fortunately, effective technologies exist to detect and repair these methane leaks. The costs of fixing these leaks can also be offset by the associated savings in energy and emissions, making a win-win situation for both industry and the environment.
In other words, fixing methane leaks isn't just important in the battle against climate change -- done right, it can pay for itself.

The real question is: How do we get oil and gas businesses (from the wellhead to the meter) to make the necessary system improvements to fix our systemic methane leaks? This is not a cheap and easy task! Let’s hope that the PG&E precedent (regulated utility that pled guilty to felony arson and 84 counts of manslaughter, then started massive overhauling of network) is not a signal of what’s to come.
Read for yourself at The Conversation US:

description:
I am delighted to announce that I have joined SPEC Oil and Gas as a Project Management Intern. My main responsibilities would be to act as a production and package fabrication engineer, where I will be monitoring and expediting the process and overcoming challenges in the engineering, procurement, construction, and commissioning of modular skid packages for various oil and gas refineries around the world. This will give me the exposure to complex engineering equipment and processes such as heat exchangers, pressure vessels, distillation towers, right from design to construction, and the sense of responsibility to deliver large scale engineering projects and meeting deadlines. Looking forward to a journey of learning and development.

description: After many challenging years followed by a pandemic and now a war in Europe, 2022 has, everything considered, been a good year for Sanco. We are now primarily working in the OBN (Ocean Bottom Nodes) niche that monitors existing oil and gas fields to increase the recovery rate. In my view, this is the cheapest, most effective, and most environmentally friendly way of securing energy, when new alternatives are years ahead. We have had an 80% overall utilisation in 2022 and have secured 100% for Q1 2023 for the vessels we manage. With excellent HSEQ stats and equal operational feedback from all our customers, our offshore and onshore teams deserve a big Thank You! Thank you also to all our partners, vendors and charterers for the excellent cooperation in 2022. “One Culture” is not a buzz concept – it works!

description:
I am proud to share that I recently graduated Cum Laude from the International Anti-corruption Academy (IACA) in Austria and recieved an Master of Arts in International Anti-corruption, compliance and collective actions.

I had the honor to be mentored by Fernando Felipe Basch when writing my masters thesis “Are signature bonuses as a bidding criterion for new oil and gas search rights a collective action problem? Signature bonus specific risks and suggested mitigating measures”.

This study has been an eye opening experience that in combination with my other master, Executive Master of Managment from BI Norwegian business school, and work experience from leading projects on three different continents has put me in an unique position to understand the global business market and to lead multinational project both domestically and international.

I am forever grateful for all the support from my family, classmates, devoted staff at IACA and Fernando Basch.

description:
I recently had the pleasure of interviewing Mr. Greg Goff, an experienced oil and gas executive. Mr. Goff was President and Chief Executive Officer of Andeavor (an integrated downstream energy company) from 2010 to 2018 and Chairman from December 2014 to 2018. In 2018 he was named by the Harvard Business Review as one of the top performing CEOs in the world. Mr. Goff is currently a board director at ExxonMobil and you may recall his name as one of the directors on the slate of the Engine No. 1 campaign. For this interview he was speaking strictly in his personal capacity.

Mr. Goff, a Republican, sees climate change as "the biggest challenge of my lifetime." He is thoughtful, realistic, and optimistic about America's ability to address this problem, one essential to its energy security. Doing so will require a strong focus on decarbonization, innovation, sensible public policies, and a price (but not a tax) on carbon. He rightly points out that meeting the vast global energy demand will require a mix of renewable and non-renewable energy resources for decades to come.

In terms of ESG, Mr. Goff is also very thoughtful about this now highly controversial topic. He is less optimistic about reducing the political polarization around ESG. That said, i really like his point that if it were ESGV, where "V" is for "Value," this would be helpful in addressing how people impose their own values on the term to define it in a way it was never intended.

Let me conclude by saying I very much enjoyed my conversation with Mr. Goff and learned a lot from him. Yes, I'm a Democrat. Yes, he's a Republican. While we don't agree on everything we agree on many things. I think this is one example of how we should be talking about climate change, the energy transition, and ESG, whatever our political affiliation. #climatechange #energytransition #carbonpricing #renewableenergy #innovation #esg #energy #decarbonization

I'm excited to announce that my latest work in Labour and Employment Law was released to the public yesterday at the Hybrid Solicitors Annual Lecture & Luncheon which held at Oriental Hotel, Victoria Island, Lagos.


Author: Bimbo Atilola
Year of Publication: 2022
Format: Hard Cover

CONTENTS
1. Human Resources Due Diligence in Mergers, Aquisitions and Takeovers
2. National Industrial Court of Nigeria and Jurisdiction over Unfair Labour Practice, and International Best Practices in Labour & Employment Matters
3. Managing Disciplinary Process at the Workplace
4. Termination of Employment without giving Reasons: Conflicting Decisions of the NIC and the Dillema of Employers of Labour
5. Validity and Enforceability of Mutual Separation Agreements in Labour and Employment Law
6. The Law and Practice of Administration of Deceased Employees’ Terminal Benefits
7. Enforceability of Employment Bonds in Nigeria
8. Legitimate Expectation Interest in Nigerian Labour and Employment Law
9. Pre-Employment HIV/AIDS Test and Termination on Account of HIV/AIDS Status
10. Trial on Record at the National Industrial Court of Nigeria: The Path Less Travelled
11. Developing and Reviewing Employee Handbooks: A Practical Guide
12. Designing Expatriate Policy Handbooks: some important legal considerations

14. Trade Unions as ‘Business Partners’: HR & Industrial Relations Managers’ Guide

16. Legal Issues in Polygraph Test at the Workplace
17. Should Maternity Leave be Annual Leave Consuming?
18. Is ‘labour Outsourcing’ a Lawful Practice in Nigeria?
19. Business Process Outsourcing and the Right to Join a Trade Union
20. Compensation for Mental Stress under the Employees’ Compensation Act: The HR Manager’s Guide
21. Post Resignation Discovery of Gross Misconducts
22. The Federal Ministry of Labour Guidelines on Contract Staffing and Outsourcing in Oil and Gas Sector: An overview
23. The Federal Ministry of Labour Guidelines on Contract Staffing and Outsourcing in Banks, Insurance Companies and Financial Institutions: An overview
24. Managing Corporate Reputational Risks: Action Plans for HR Managers

description:
This morning, more than 50 delegates representing about 25 well-known companies from various industries - oil and gas, banking, energy and power, logistics and telco- sat in a room to participate in the first meeting of data management professionals to discuss the formation of the professional association whose main goal is to promote data culture and contribute to the journey of making the nation more data-driven. Without hesitation, we voted yes for the establishment of DAMA chapter in Malaysia.

We would like to take this opportunity to thank the Chief of Data Officer of PETRONAS, Datin Ts. Habsah Nordin and her team for leading the initiative and being the key players. This event is also a place for me and my team to interact with other data professionals from other organizations in Malaysia and a good opportunity to meet friends and ex-colleagues.

Special thanks to Yi Shin Ng for the invitation and it was great to see Rawaida Kamarudin, Zohairen Muhamad Sori, and Lena Boey again, and to finally meet Syakiriin M. Zulkifli, Brian Ho and others in person!

I look forward to contributing and, as always, thanks to my colleagues, Nur Alisliyana Jamaludin and Muhammad Zulfadzhli Ahmad Zolfi for taking the time to come to this event today.

#dama #analyticsjourney

Transocean Offshore Rotational Jobs
Transocean Ltd (Transocean) is a provider of offshore contract drilling services to the oil and gas sector. It specializes in the technically demanding regions of the global offshore drilling business with a particular focus on deepwater and harsh environment drilling services. The company’s fleet consists of different types of floaters, including ultra-deepwater, harsh environment, deepwater and midwater, and high specification jackups. Its customer base includes international, government and independent oil companies. It offers services to customers in the North America, South America, Europe, and other regions. Transocean is headquartered in Steinhausen, Zug, Switzerland.

description:
The World Will Never Agree to Phase Out Petroleum. And That’s OK

Washington Post: The world has failed to come to an agreement to stop burning fossil fuels. After two weeks of negotiations, a draft decision at the United Nations COP27 climate conference in Sharm El Sheikh, Egypt, promised a compensation fund for climate change damages but fell short of a push from the US and Europe for a “phase-down” of oil, gas and coal.

In fact, it’s worse than that. Although a phase-down of coal was agreed at last year’s Glasgow conference, other fossil fuels are going to remain immune. Twenty years from now, we are still likely to see global climate meetings failing to agree to a phase-down (let alone phase-out) of fossil fuels. And that’s OK — because what matters is not the words in an international agreement, but whether our carbon emissions are falling fast enough. On that front, the prospects are far better.

There’s a simple reason why getting consensus at UN climate meetings is so hard. The verbiage released at the end of COP meetings isn’t just words, but a quasi-legal text that serves to flesh out the binding commitments of the 2015 Paris Agreement. If just one of the 193 parties to that treaty objects to the conference decision, there will be no deal to announce. That’s why campaigners, fossil-fuel lobbyists and diplomats fight so hard over every emphasis. The COP decision isn’t exactly law, but it still influences the actions of governments and companies in the real world.

As we lumber along the road to net zero, a significant number of UN members are getting uncomfortable about the destination. The Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries numbers 13 states, with 11 more in the OPEC+ grouping. Throw in non-OPEC+ countries highly dependent on oil and gas — like Guyana, Qatar, and Turkmenistan — and you have as many as 50 delegations, depending on how you draw the line. For that group, equivalent to a quarter of UN member states, a commitment to phase out petroleum is a vow to shrink their own economies....

Source: Washington Post

For more details, refer to the link below.

#oilgas #energy #investing #alternativeenergy

Offshore Construction Manager x2, AGR are working with our Oil & Gas E&P Operator client on a 12 month contract requirement UK, 2/2 rotational role, Limited Company or PAYE basis.

· Manage and deliver all the Construction and Anomaly Activities across all offshore assets
· Accountable for all the Construction Projects and Modifications Scopes in accordance with processes
· Member of the offshore leadership team, reporting direct to the OIM

· Sufficient knowledge and experience of working within and supervising a multi-disciplined team
· Good organisational skills, anticipates problems and identifies solutions
· Proactively drives progress and demonstrates responsibility for performance
· Proven relationship-builder across various disciplines and functions
· Excellent communicator, able to present in a clear and concise manner
· Able to quickly adapt as per the needs of the organisation
· Proficient in the use of Excel, Word, Outlook, and PowerPoint

Requirements
· Significant experience of working within the Oil and Gas industry
· Demonstrable supervisory experience in an offshore environment
· Working experience of operating constraints including Safe Isolation and Reinstatement of Plant on mature and late life assets
· Significant experience managing multiple contractors cross a wide range of scopes
· Demonstrable experience dealing with the safe and efficient execution of offshore project/modifications
· Previous experience in a similar role is essential
· HNC in Construction/Fabrication

Applicants must have the right to work in the UK unassisted.
For full details, please send CV to Rhona.Ritchie@agr.com
